title: How to Cook Broccoli in a Pan

methods.name: Steaming Your Broccoli in a Pan

steps.headline: Cut the florets into ⁄8 inch (0.32 cm) pieces.
steps.description: Peel 1 pound (16 oz) of broccoli stalk, removing the florets. Slice them into pieces that are about 1 inch (2.5 cm) in size, then cut the stalk in half horizontally. After slicing them horizontally, take each half and slice it vertically into pieces that are ⁄8 inch (0.32 cm) thick and place them at the bottom of a 2.5 US quarts (10.0  c) to 3 US quarts (12  c) saucepan.

steps.headline: Add the broccoli, water, and salt to a saucepan and turn the burner to high.
steps.description: Use ⁄3 cup (2.7  fl oz) of water and a pinch of salt. Put the broccoli florets on top of the water and set the burner to high heat.

steps.headline: Place the lid on the pan and allow your broccoli to cook for 3 minutes.
steps.description: Allow your water to maintain a light simmer, while stirring your broccoli about every minute. You do not need to use a steamer basket for this method.

steps.headline: Turn the heat down to low, cover the pan, and cook it for an additional 3 minutes.
steps.description: Once the 3 minutes are up and your broccoli is at your desired consistency, remove it promptly from the heat. Drain any excess water and serve while it is hot. For more flavor, add in 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of unsalted butter and stir it in with your broccoli. You can also drizzle your favorite dressing or sauce on top.

steps.headline: Use a cast iron skillet to heat 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of olive oil.
steps.description: Set your stove to medium-low heat and allow your oil to heat for approximately 2-3 minutes. You can also use a heavy-bottom pan if you do not have a cast iron skillet available. Heavy-bottom pans and skillets have a thicker base, which will allow heat to be distributed evenly from the stovetop burner to your broccoli.

steps.headline: Cut the broccoli into long, thin pieces.
steps.description: Cut a head of broccoli in half, then place the flat side down on your cutting board. Cut the florets long-ways to keep the stems attached to each floret top. Slice from the base of your floret to the base of the stem to keep your broccoli pieces long and thin. Using an entire head of broccoli will help cut down on food waste and save you money!

steps.headline: Add your broccoli slices to the pan of oil and sprinkle them with salt.
steps.description: As you are placing your broccoli in the pan ensure that as many pieces as possible are directly touching the bottom of your pan. After all of your pieces of broccoli have been arranged, sprinkle ⁄2 teaspoon (2.5 mL) of salt and pepper over the top of your broccoli.

steps.headline: Cook the broccoli uncovered for 5 minutes, then season the other side.
steps.description: Do not disturb your broccoli during this time, as you want one side to cook thoroughly before switching to the other. After the 5 minutes are up, flip your broccoli pieces so that the side that was facing down is now facing up. Season this side of your broccoli by adding another ⁄2 teaspoon (2.5 mL) of salt and pepper over the top. For better results keep as many broccoli pieces as possible directly touching the bottom of the pan.

steps.headline: Cover your pan and allow your broccoli to cook for another 3 minutes.
steps.description: Allow the slices to cook thoroughly, without stirring, before serving. Your broccoli will be completely done when there is a brown and crunchy texture to the outside. For best results, serve your broccoli immediately after it is finished cooking and while it is still hot.

methods.name: Roasting Your Broccoli in a Pan

steps.headline: Cut the tops of your broccoli into 1 inch (2.5 cm) pieces.
steps.description: After rinsing your broccoli under warm water, begin by cutting the tops of your broccoli into pieces that are 1 inch (2.5 cm) in diameter. The stems of your broccoli should also be cut into pieces that are about a ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) thick. Washing your broccoli before use is not required.

steps.headline: Heat 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of olive oil in your frying pan.
steps.description: Place your pan over medium heat to begin heating your oil. As your oil begins to heat up, lower the heat slightly, to keep the oil from burning or becoming too hot.

steps.headline: Add in 1 large clove of thinly, sliced garlic.
steps.description: Stirring the mixture consistently, cook the garlic thoroughly for about 1 minute or until it looks golden in color. After your garlic is cooked completely, use a slotted spoon to remove the garlic from the pan and place it into a separate bowl. Olive oil can be substituted with other vegetable oils or nut oils if preferred.

steps.headline: Increase the stove's heat to medium-high and add in your sliced broccoli.
steps.description: Upon adding in your broccoli, combine a pinch of salt and pepper for seasoning and sprinkle it on top. For more flavor you can add in ⁄4 teaspoon (1.2 mL) of red pepper flakes.

steps.headline: Add water and steam the broccoli for 3 minutes.
steps.description: Add 3 tablespoons (44 mL) of water to your pan of broccoli. Once the water is added, cover your broccoli and allow it to steam for about 3 minutes. When your broccoli is done steaming it will turn a vibrant, green color. If your broccoli is closer to an olive green, it is overdone. Do not exceed 5 minutes when steaming your broccoli.

steps.headline: Cook the broccoli uncovered for another 1-2 minutes.
steps.description: Stir your broccoli occasionally until it is lightly browned. All of the water in the pan will evaporate and your broccoli will be tender with a crispy outside. Color alone can help you determine if your broccoli is done steaming. Or you can slide a fork into the broccoli to see if it's ready. When it's done, the fork will slide effortlessly in and out of the stem.

steps.headline: Sprinkle the garlic on top of your cooked broccoli.
steps.description: Be sure and serve your broccoli right away.

steps.headline: Chop the broccoli then add it to a pan with garlic and butter.
steps.description: Rinse your broccoli and remove the stems. After removing the stems, you may want to trim any of the larger florets to fit your preferred size. Finely chop 2 cloves of garlic and place them in your skillet. Add the broccoli florets to the skillet along with 3 tablespoons (44 mL) of butter.

steps.headline: Turn your grill onto medium heat and place your pan on the rack.
steps.description: Close the cover on your grill and allow most of the butter in your pan to melt.

steps.headline: Cook the broccoli on the grill for 5 minutes, then season it.
steps.description: Add the broccoli to the pan with the melted broccoli. After the 5 minutes is up, season your broccoli by adding a ⁄2 tablespoon (7.4 mL) of salt and pepper. Grill heat may vary depending on the size and strength of your grill. If you notice your broccoli getting too dark, turn down your heat.

steps.headline: Allow your broccoli to cook for an additional 5 minutes.
steps.description: Let your broccoli sit until all of the butter in the pan has been absorbed. Depending on your grill it may take a little less than 5 minutes to get your broccoli nicely charred. You will know when your broccoli is done cooking by its crispy and crunchy consistency. If your broccoli has too many charred spots on it before the 5 minutes are up, go ahead and remove it from the heat. Pan-grilled broccoli makes a great side dish for any of your favorite meals.
